What is the difference between SATA II and 150?

What is the difference between SATA II and 150?

 
 SATA/150 is a 150 MB/s maxiumum burst tranfer rate.
 
 SATA II is actually a comitee that wrote specifications.....what you are thinking of is the SATA II 3 GB/s maximum burst transfer rate protocall that they authored.
 
 In reality, you can expect more like 300 MB/s from sata II, unless you are ready to kick out some serious cash for MBs and drives/

The problem I'm having is that of the computers I own that have SATA capability, they don't specificy which.
 
 Would there be a problem if I had a 150 connection yet bought a II drive?

The problem I'm having is that of the computers I own that have SATA capability, they don't specificy which.
 
 Would there be a problem if I had a 150 connection yet bought a II drive?

 
 Shouldn't be. The drive will just run at the lower speed. If they do not specify SATA II they are probably SATA 150. You pay extra for SATA II.

Shouldn't be. The drive will just run at the lower speed. If they do not specify SATA II they are probably SATA 150. You pay extra for SATA II.

 
 I really wish they'd document that. I can't find it anywhere. The motherboard manual just says SATA and the online documentation isn't any better.

I really wish they'd document that. I can't find it anywhere. The motherboard manual just says SATA and the online documentation isn't any better.

 
 You are going to have a hard time finding a functional MB with SATA II, and unless you are running at least 3 processors there is no point since you cannot process that much data that quickly anyway. The exception would be a raid array in either stripiong or dual mode. A few Raid setups actualy support SATA II. Our server at work supports it, and it cost nearly $600 extra for true SATA II support. If your machine truly supports it and has the processing power to handle it, SATA II makes the machine noticably faster.

well, they got dual core now emoticon_rolleyes 
 
 
 anyway, I would say go with a Seagate SATA drive as those are without a doubt the best harddrives out there.
